booking-com.name: Gillian Tans
booking-com.bio: Dutch businesswoman who served as CEO of Booking.com from 2016 to 2019, having joined the company in 2002 and risen through its leadership ranks.

booking-com.name: Geert-Jan Bruinsma
booking-com.bio: Dutch entrepreneur who founded Bookings.nl in 1996, the online hotel reservation startup that evolved into the global travel platform Booking.com.

booking-com.name: Kees Koolen
booking-com.bio: Early CEO of Booking.com who led the company during its critical growth phase before its acquisition by Priceline Group in 2005.

niw-nieuw-isra-lietisch-weekblad.name: Ronny Naftaniel
niw-nieuw-isra-lietisch-weekblad.bio: Prominent Dutch-Jewish communal leader and former director of CIDI who has contributed to the NIW as a leading voice on antisemitism and Jewish affairs in the Netherlands.

niw-nieuw-isra-lietisch-weekblad.name: Hans Knoop
niw-nieuw-isra-lietisch-weekblad.bio: Dutch-Jewish investigative journalist known for exposing Dutch Nazi collaborator Pieter Menten in the 1970s, who contributed to Dutch Jewish media.

niw-nieuw-isra-lietisch-weekblad.name: Philip Mechanicus
niw-nieuw-isra-lietisch-weekblad.bio: Dutch-Jewish journalist who wrote for various Amsterdam newspapers and kept a diary in Westerbork transit camp that became a key Holocaust document.

joods-historisch-museum.name: Judith Belinfante
joods-historisch-museum.bio: Pioneering museum director who oversaw the reopening and transformation of the Joods Historisch Museum in 1987 in a restored Ashkenazi synagogue complex.

joods-historisch-museum.name: Julie-Marthe Cohen
joods-historisch-museum.bio: Expert in Jewish ceremonial art and material culture who has served as chief curator at the Joods Historisch Museum, shaping its exhibitions and collections.

joods-historisch-museum.name: Joel Cahen
joods-historisch-museum.bio: Former staff member at the Joods Historisch Museum who later founded Jewish heritage digital initiatives and contributed to online Jewish museum projects.

centraal-joods-overleg-cjo.name: Ron van der Wieken
centraal-joods-overleg-cjo.bio: Dutch-Jewish communal leader who chaired the Centraal Joods Overleg, the umbrella body coordinating Jewish organizational representation in the Netherlands.

centraal-joods-overleg-cjo.name: Ruben Vis
centraal-joods-overleg-cjo.bio: Served in administrative roles within the CJO while also holding leadership positions in the NIK, coordinating Dutch Jewish communal affairs.

centraal-joods-overleg-cjo.name: Hanna Luden
centraal-joods-overleg-cjo.bio: Served as director of CIDI (Centre for Information and Documentation on Israel) and participated in CJO coordination of Dutch Jewish community advocacy.

nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootschap-.name: Binyomin Jacobs
nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootschap-.bio: Senior Orthodox rabbinical authority of the Netherlands, serving as inter-provincial chief rabbi under the NIK framework for Dutch Ashkenazi congregations.

nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootschap-.name: Lody van de Kamp
nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootschap-.bio: Dutch Orthodox rabbi affiliated with the NIK who became widely known as a media personality and commentator on Jewish life and culture in the Netherlands.

nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootschap-.name: Raphael Evers
nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootschap-.bio: Dutch rabbi who served within the NIK rabbinate, known for his scholarly publications on Jewish philosophy and his contributions to Dutch Jewish religious education.

portuguese-synagogue-of-amsterdam.name: Isaac Aboab da Fonseca
portuguese-synagogue-of-amsterdam.bio: Hakham of the Amsterdam Portuguese community and considered the first appointed rabbi in the Americas during his time in Dutch Brazil.

portuguese-synagogue-of-amsterdam.name: Manasseh Ben Israel
portuguese-synagogue-of-amsterdam.bio: Renowned Portuguese-Jewish rabbi and scholar of the Amsterdam community who petitioned Oliver Cromwell for the readmission of Jews to England in 1655.

portuguese-synagogue-of-amsterdam.name: Pinhas Toledano
portuguese-synagogue-of-amsterdam.bio: Served as chief rabbi of the Portuguese-Israelite community of Amsterdam, maintaining the Sephardic liturgical and rabbinical traditions of the historic congregation.

anne-frank-house.name: Otto Frank
anne-frank-house.bio: Father of Anne Frank and sole surviving member of the immediate Frank family, who established the Anne Frank House museum in 1957 to preserve his daughter's legacy.

anne-frank-house.name: Ronald Leopold
anne-frank-house.bio: Museum professional serving as executive director of the Anne Frank House, overseeing its operations as one of the most visited museums in the Netherlands.

anne-frank-house.name: Hans Westra
anne-frank-house.bio: Led the Anne Frank House as managing director for many years, expanding its educational programs and international outreach on tolerance and human rights.

jewish-historical-museum-amsterdam.name: Judith Belinfante
jewish-historical-museum-amsterdam.bio: Museum director who oversaw the 1987 reopening of the Jewish Historical Museum in restored Ashkenazi synagogue buildings as Amsterdam's principal museum of Dutch Jewish life.

jewish-historical-museum-amsterdam.name: Julie-Marthe Cohen
jewish-historical-museum-amsterdam.bio: Curator specializing in Jewish ceremonial objects and material culture who led the museum's exhibition and collection development programs.

jewish-historical-museum-amsterdam.name: Joel Cahen
jewish-historical-museum-amsterdam.bio: Contributed to the Jewish Historical Museum's curatorial work before going on to develop pioneering digital platforms for Jewish cultural heritage.

westerbork-transit-camp-memorial.name: Dirk Mulder
westerbork-transit-camp-memorial.bio: Longtime director of the Westerbork Memorial Center who developed it into a major Holocaust remembrance and education site in the Netherlands.

westerbork-transit-camp-memorial.name: Jules Schelvis
westerbork-transit-camp-memorial.bio: Dutch Holocaust survivor deported via Westerbork to Sobibor who later became a leading historian of the transit camp and the Sobibor extermination camp.

westerbork-transit-camp-memorial.name: Guido Abuys
westerbork-transit-camp-memorial.bio: Head of collections and research at Camp Westerbork Memorial, responsible for preserving artifacts and historical documentation related to the transit camp.

nik-nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootsc.name: Lody van de Kamp
nik-nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootsc.bio: Dutch rabbi affiliated with the NIK known for his accessible public commentary on Jewish practices and his contributions to Dutch media and journalism.

nik-nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootsc.name: Raphael Evers
nik-nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootsc.bio: Rabbi within the Dutch Orthodox rabbinate who has authored numerous works on Jewish thought and served congregations under the NIK umbrella.

nik-nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootsc.name: Ruben Vis
nik-nederlands-isra-litisch-kerkgenootsc.bio: Longtime secretary-general of the NIK, managing the administrative and organizational affairs of the Dutch Ashkenazi Jewish religious community.

national-holocaust-museum-amsterdam.name: Frits Barend
national-holocaust-museum-amsterdam.bio: Dutch-Jewish television journalist and author whose parents survived the Holocaust, known for his public advocacy for Holocaust remembrance in the Netherlands.

national-holocaust-museum-amsterdam.name: Jacques Grishaver
national-holocaust-museum-amsterdam.bio: Dutch Holocaust survivor hidden as a child during WWII who became an advocate for Holocaust education and the establishment of the National Holocaust Museum.

national-holocaust-museum-amsterdam.name: Johannes Houwink ten Cate
national-holocaust-museum-amsterdam.bio: Dutch historian and professor specializing in the Holocaust in the Netherlands who contributed scholarly expertise to the development of the museum's narrative.

grupo-televisa.name: Bernardo Gómez
grupo-televisa.bio: Served as co-CEO of Grupo Televisa, managing the company's broadcasting and content operations for Latin America's dominant Spanish-language media conglomerate.

grupo-televisa.name: Alfonso de Angoitia
grupo-televisa.bio: Mexican attorney and executive who served as executive vice president and co-CEO of Grupo Televisa, overseeing its corporate strategy.

grupo-televisa.name: Emilio Azcárraga Vidaurreta
grupo-televisa.bio: Mexican media pioneer who founded the broadcasting empire that became Grupo Televisa, establishing XEW radio and Mexico's first television station.

grupo-carso.name: Carlos Slim Domit
grupo-carso.bio: Eldest son of Carlos Slim Helú who serves as chairman of Grupo Carso and Telmex, continuing the family's leadership of Mexico's largest industrial conglomerate.

grupo-carso.name: Patrick Slim Domit
grupo-carso.bio: Son of Carlos Slim Helú who serves on the boards of various Grupo Carso subsidiaries and oversees key business divisions within the conglomerate.

grupo-carso.name: Juan Antonio Pérez Simón
grupo-carso.bio: Longtime Grupo Carso executive and close associate of Carlos Slim who also became known as one of Latin America's foremost art collectors.

tribunal-tarbut.name: Jacobo Zabludovsky
tribunal-tarbut.bio: Legendary Mexican television anchor and journalist of Jewish origin who was the foremost news broadcaster in Mexican media history and active in Jewish cultural circles.

tribunal-tarbut.name: Enrique Krauze
tribunal-tarbut.bio: Prominent Mexican public intellectual, historian, and publisher of Jewish origin who has contributed to Mexican Jewish cultural discourse and literary life.

tribunal-tarbut.name: Margo Glantz
tribunal-tarbut.bio: Mexican author and literary scholar of Jewish-Ukrainian descent, known for her memoir about Jewish immigrant life in Mexico, active in Jewish cultural organizations.

centro-deportivo-israelita.name: Elías Sourasky
centro-deportivo-israelita.bio: Mexican-Jewish businessman and philanthropist of Lithuanian origin who was a major benefactor of Jewish communal institutions in Mexico City.

centro-deportivo-israelita.name: Moisés Saba Masri
centro-deportivo-israelita.bio: Mexican-Jewish billionaire businessman and philanthropist who supported numerous Jewish communal institutions in Mexico including community centers.

centro-deportivo-israelita.name: Marcos Shabot
centro-deportivo-israelita.bio: Prominent Mexican Jewish communal leader who has held leadership positions across multiple Jewish organizations in Mexico City.

kadima-community.name: Salomón Cohen
kadima-community.bio: Leader within Mexico City's Kadima community, which serves Jewish families of Aleppo (Halabi) Syrian origin and is one of the largest Sephardic communities in the Americas.

kadima-community.name: Isaac Hamui
kadima-community.bio: Served as president of the Kadima community in Mexico City, representing one of the well-organized branches of Mexico's Sephardic Jewish population.

kadima-community.name: Moisés Assa
kadima-community.bio: Mexican Jewish communal leader who has held leadership roles in multiple Jewish organizations, contributing to the institutional life of the Sephardic community.

museo-memoria-y-tolerancia.name: Ella Leibovitz
museo-memoria-y-tolerancia.bio: Holocaust survivor and educator who co-founded the Museo Memoria y Tolerancia in Mexico City, dedicating her life to Holocaust education in Latin America.

museo-memoria-y-tolerancia.name: Mario Torroella Caballero
museo-memoria-y-tolerancia.bio: Museum professional who has served in leadership at the Museo Memoria y Tolerancia, overseeing its exhibitions and educational programs on genocide and human rights.

museo-memoria-y-tolerancia.name: Dalia Zaga
museo-memoria-y-tolerancia.bio: Has contributed to the museum's educational and cultural programming alongside founder Sharon Zaga, developing outreach initiatives on tolerance and social responsibility.

comit-central-de-la-comunidad-jud-a-de-m.name: Moisés Assa
comit-central-de-la-comunidad-jud-a-de-m.bio: Served as president of the Comité Central de la Comunidad Judía de México, the central representative body of Mexico's approximately 50,000-strong Jewish community.

comit-central-de-la-comunidad-jud-a-de-m.name: Renée Dayan Shabot
comit-central-de-la-comunidad-jud-a-de-m.bio: Mexican-Jewish historian and communal leader who has documented Mexican Jewish history and served in leadership roles including at Tribuna Israelita.

comit-central-de-la-comunidad-jud-a-de-m.name: Salomón Alfie
comit-central-de-la-comunidad-jud-a-de-m.bio: Mexican Jewish communal figure who has held leadership positions in the organized Jewish community of Mexico, contributing to its institutional governance.

colegio-hebreo-maguen-david.name: Sión Cohen
colegio-hebreo-maguen-david.bio: Leader within the Colegio Hebreo Maguen David, one of Mexico City's premier Jewish schools serving the Syrian Sephardic community with bilingual education.

colegio-hebreo-maguen-david.name: Isaac Saad
colegio-hebreo-maguen-david.bio: Mexican-Jewish communal figure connected to the Maguen David institutions serving Mexico City's large Damascene Jewish community.

colegio-hebreo-maguen-david.name: Esther Hamui Halabe
colegio-hebreo-maguen-david.bio: Mexican academic and sociologist of Syrian-Jewish descent who has researched and documented the educational and communal life of Mexican Sephardic Jewry.

tribuna-israelita.name: Renée Dayan Shabot
tribuna-israelita.bio: Mexican-Jewish historian and communal leader who directed Tribuna Israelita for years, promoting interfaith dialogue and combating antisemitism in Mexico.

tribuna-israelita.name: Sergio Nudelstejer
tribuna-israelita.bio: Served as director of Tribuna Israelita, leading the organization's mission to represent Jewish community perspectives in Mexican public discourse.

tribuna-israelita.name: Mauricio Lulka
tribuna-israelita.bio: Mexican-Jewish communal leader involved in Tribuna Israelita's efforts to promote understanding between the Jewish community and broader Mexican society.

kidzania.name: Maricruz Arrubarrena
kidzania.bio: Served as chief operating officer of KidZania, helping scale the interactive children's entertainment concept from Mexico City to over 25 locations worldwide.

kidzania.name: Fernando Pardo
kidzania.bio: Executive who has served in KidZania's senior leadership, helping manage the company's global expansion of its children's role-playing theme park concept.

kidzania.name: Carlos Slim Domit
kidzania.bio: As chairman of Grupo Carso, has been connected to investment interests in KidZania, which originated in Mexico City's Santa Fe district in 1999.

comite-central-comunidad-judia-mexico.name: Marcos Shabot
comite-central-comunidad-judia-mexico.bio: Has served as president of the central committee representing Mexico's Jewish community, coordinating communal affairs and external relations.

comite-central-comunidad-judia-mexico.name: Moisés Assa
comite-central-comunidad-judia-mexico.bio: Prominent Mexican Jewish communal leader who served as president of the organized Jewish community structure in Mexico City.

comite-central-comunidad-judia-mexico.name: Renée Dayan Shabot
comite-central-comunidad-judia-mexico.bio: Historian and communal leader who has served Mexican Jewish organizations in advocacy and documentation of Jewish community life in Mexico.

sigmund-freud-museum.name: Monika Pessler
sigmund-freud-museum.bio: Art historian and museum director who has led the Sigmund Freud Museum in Vienna, overseeing its major renovation and expansion completed in 2020.

sigmund-freud-museum.name: Anna Freud
sigmund-freud-museum.bio: Sigmund Freud's youngest daughter who became a pioneering psychoanalyst in her own right, specializing in child psychology. The museum preserves the family's history.

sigmund-freud-museum.name: Josef Breuer
sigmund-freud-museum.bio: Austrian physician and physiologist who collaborated with Freud on 'Studies on Hysteria' (1895), making foundational contributions to the development of psychoanalysis.

j-disches-museum-wien.name: Danielle Spera
j-disches-museum-wien.bio: Austrian journalist and museum director who led the Jüdisches Museum Wien for over a decade, revitalizing its exhibitions and community engagement programs.

j-disches-museum-wien.name: Karl Schwarz
j-disches-museum-wien.bio: Art historian who served as the first director of the Jewish Museum Vienna when it was originally founded in 1895, building its initial collections before the Nazi closure.

j-disches-museum-wien.name: Werner Hanak-Lettner
j-disches-museum-wien.bio: Austrian curator and exhibition designer who has developed major exhibitions at the Jüdisches Museum Wien documenting Austrian Jewish history and culture.

lauder-chabad-campus-wien.name: Rabbi Jacob Biderman
lauder-chabad-campus-wien.bio: Chabad-Lubavitch emissary who directs Chabad of Austria and manages the Lauder Chabad Campus in Vienna, providing Jewish education and community services.

lauder-chabad-campus-wien.name: Georg Muzicant
lauder-chabad-campus-wien.bio: Austrian Jewish communal figure involved in the governance of the Lauder Chabad Campus Wien and its educational and religious programming.

lauder-chabad-campus-wien.name: Rabbi Shaya Boas
lauder-chabad-campus-wien.bio: Serves in the educational leadership of the Lauder Chabad Campus, which includes the Lauder Business School and the Lauder Chabad school system.

israelitische-kultusgemeinde-wien-jewish.name: Ariel Muzicant
israelitische-kultusgemeinde-wien-jewish.bio: Austrian-Jewish businessman who served as president of the IKG Wien from 1998 to 2012, leading the community through a period of institutional revitalization.

israelitische-kultusgemeinde-wien-jewish.name: Paul Chaim Eisenberg
israelitische-kultusgemeinde-wien-jewish.bio: Served as chief rabbi of Vienna for over three decades, becoming one of Austria's most recognizable Jewish figures and an advocate for interfaith dialogue.

israelitische-kultusgemeinde-wien-jewish.name: Schlomo Hofmeister
israelitische-kultusgemeinde-wien-jewish.bio: Serves as community rabbi of the IKG Wien, leading religious services and representing the Jewish community in Vienna's public and interfaith affairs.

mauthausen-memorial.name: Simon Wiesenthal
mauthausen-memorial.bio: Austrian Holocaust survivor liberated from Mauthausen in 1945 who dedicated his life to tracking down Nazi war criminals, founding the Documentation Centre in Vienna.

mauthausen-memorial.name: Hans Maršálek
mauthausen-memorial.bio: Czech-Austrian survivor of Mauthausen who became the camp's leading historian, authoring the definitive history and serving as curator of the memorial.

mauthausen-memorial.name: Bertrand Perz
mauthausen-memorial.bio: Austrian historian at the University of Vienna specializing in the history of the Mauthausen concentration camp system, a key scholarly authority on the memorial.

jewish-museum-vienna.name: Danielle Spera
jewish-museum-vienna.bio: Austrian journalist turned museum director who revitalized the Jewish Museum Vienna during her tenure, expanding its exhibitions and public programming.

jewish-museum-vienna.name: Karl Schwarz
jewish-museum-vienna.bio: Art historian who founded and led the original Jewish Museum Vienna in 1895, making it one of the world's first Jewish museums before its closure by the Nazis.

jewish-museum-vienna.name: Felicitas Heimann-Jelinek
jewish-museum-vienna.bio: Museum curator and scholar who served as chief curator at the Jewish Museum Vienna, developing groundbreaking exhibitions on Austrian Jewish history and identity.

stadttempel-vienna-city-temple.name: Paul Chaim Eisenberg
stadttempel-vienna-city-temple.bio: Served as chief rabbi of Vienna for over thirty years at the Stadttempel, the only synagogue in Vienna to survive Kristallnacht due to its concealed location within a residential block.

stadttempel-vienna-city-temple.name: Schlomo Hofmeister
stadttempel-vienna-city-temple.bio: Current community rabbi of Vienna who leads services at the Stadttempel and serves as a public representative of the Jewish community.

stadttempel-vienna-city-temple.name: Isaak Noa Mannheimer
stadttempel-vienna-city-temple.bio: Founding preacher of the Stadttempel who led the congregation from its opening in 1826, becoming the most influential Jewish religious leader in the Habsburg Empire.

vienna-wiesenthal-institute.name: Simon Wiesenthal
vienna-wiesenthal-institute.bio: Austrian Holocaust survivor and renowned Nazi hunter whose legacy inspired the founding of the Vienna Wiesenthal Institute for Holocaust Studies.

vienna-wiesenthal-institute.name: Éva Kovács
vienna-wiesenthal-institute.bio: Hungarian-Austrian historian and sociologist who has served as academic director of the VWI, leading its research programs on the Holocaust and genocide.

vienna-wiesenthal-institute.name: Jochen Böhler
vienna-wiesenthal-institute.bio: German-Austrian historian who has directed the VWI's research programs on Holocaust studies, antisemitism, and racism in contemporary Europe.

jewish-community-of-vienna.name: Ariel Muzicant
jewish-community-of-vienna.bio: Austrian-Jewish businessman and communal leader who served as president of Vienna's Jewish community from 1998 to 2012, revitalizing its institutions.

jewish-community-of-vienna.name: Paul Chaim Eisenberg
jewish-community-of-vienna.bio: Served as chief rabbi of the Jewish Community of Vienna for over three decades, widely known in Austrian public life for interfaith leadership.

jewish-community-of-vienna.name: Paul Grosz
jewish-community-of-vienna.bio: Austrian Jewish leader who served as president of the IKG Wien during the critical post-Cold War period, guiding the community through restitution negotiations.

mus-e-juif-de-belgique.name: Philippe Blondin
mus-e-juif-de-belgique.bio: Served as president of the board of the Musée Juif de Belgique, which documents the history and culture of Jews in Belgium from the medieval period to the present.

mus-e-juif-de-belgique.name: Alexandre Zanzer
mus-e-juif-de-belgique.bio: Auschwitz survivor and prominent Belgian Jewish community figure who contributed to Holocaust remembrance at the museum, killed in the 2014 terrorist attack.

mus-e-juif-de-belgique.name: Yohan Benizri
mus-e-juif-de-belgique.bio: As president of the CCOJB, connected to the governance and communal support structure of the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels.

comit-de-coordination-des-organisations-.name: Joël Rubinfeld
comit-de-coordination-des-organisations-.bio: Belgian-Jewish advocate who served as president of the CCOJB and co-founded the European Jewish Parliament, leading Belgian Jewish communal representation.

comit-de-coordination-des-organisations-.name: Maurice Sosnowski
comit-de-coordination-des-organisations-.bio: Served as president of the CCOJB, coordinating the interests of Belgian Jewish organizations in relations with government and civil society.

comit-de-coordination-des-organisations-.name: Henri Bentata
comit-de-coordination-des-organisations-.bio: Belgian-Jewish communal leader involved in CCOJB's coordination of Jewish organizational life, advocacy, and communal governance in Belgium.

kazerne-dossin-memorial.name: Herman Van Goethem
kazerne-dossin-memorial.bio: Belgian historian and former rector of the University of Antwerp who served as founding director of the Kazerne Dossin Memorial, documenting the deportation of 25,000 Jews from Belgium.

kazerne-dossin-memorial.name: Laurence Schram
kazerne-dossin-memorial.bio: Historian and senior researcher at Kazerne Dossin specializing in the history of the Jewish deportations from Belgium, author of key works on the Mechelen transit camp.

kazerne-dossin-memorial.name: Ward Adriaens
kazerne-dossin-memorial.bio: Museum professional who has served in the directorship of the Kazerne Dossin Memorial, overseeing its exhibitions on the Holocaust in Belgium and human rights education.

antwerp-diamond-district.name: Ari Epstein
antwerp-diamond-district.bio: CEO of the Antwerp World Diamond Centre who represents Antwerp's diamond industry, historically dominated by Jewish traders since the 15th century.

antwerp-diamond-district.name: Ehud Arye Laniado
antwerp-diamond-district.bio: Israeli-Belgian diamond dealer and industry figure who operated in Antwerp's diamond district and was known for brokering major gemstone sales worldwide.

antwerp-diamond-district.name: Sylvain Goldberg
antwerp-diamond-district.bio: Veteran of the Antwerp diamond trade and leader in the diamond bourse, representing the historic Jewish presence in Antwerp's gem industry.

antwerp-jewish-community.name: Aron Berger
antwerp-jewish-community.bio: Prominent member of Antwerp's Orthodox Jewish community, one of Europe's most vibrant haredi communities centered around the diamond district.

antwerp-jewish-community.name: Rabbi Dovid Moshe Lieberman
antwerp-jewish-community.bio: Serves as chief rabbi of the Machsike Hadass community, the main Orthodox rabbinical authority in Antwerp's large and active Jewish community.

antwerp-jewish-community.name: Philip Carmel
antwerp-jewish-community.bio: Belgian-Jewish communal figure and policy advisor active in Antwerp Jewish communal affairs and the European Jewish Association.

jewish-museum-of-belgium-brussels.name: Philippe Blondin
jewish-museum-of-belgium-brussels.bio: Led the board of the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, which was the target of a deadly terrorist attack in May 2014.

jewish-museum-of-belgium-brussels.name: Chouna Lomponda
jewish-museum-of-belgium-brussels.bio: Served as director of the Jewish Museum of Belgium, managing its collections and exhibitions on Belgian Jewish history and culture.

jewish-museum-of-belgium-brussels.name: Joël Rubinfeld
jewish-museum-of-belgium-brussels.bio: Belgian-Jewish leader and former CCOJB president who has supported the Jewish Museum's role in preserving Belgian Jewish heritage.

coordinating-committee-of-jewish-organis.name: Joël Rubinfeld
coordinating-committee-of-jewish-organis.bio: Belgian-Jewish advocate and co-founder of the European Jewish Parliament who led the CCOJB's coordination of Belgian Jewish organizations.

coordinating-committee-of-jewish-organis.name: Maurice Sosnowski
coordinating-committee-of-jewish-organis.bio: Led the CCOJB as president, serving as the principal coordinator of Belgian Jewish communal representation and advocacy.

coordinating-committee-of-jewish-organis.name: Viviane Teitelbaum
coordinating-committee-of-jewish-organis.bio: Belgian-Jewish politician and communal leader who has been active in CCOJB-affiliated organizations and advocacy against antisemitism in Belgium.

antwerp-diamond-centre.name: Nicky Oppenheimer
antwerp-diamond-centre.bio: South African billionaire and former chairman of De Beers whose family's diamond empire has deep historic ties to Antwerp's diamond trading centre.

antwerp-diamond-centre.name: Peter Meeus
antwerp-diamond-centre.bio: Served as chairman of the Antwerp Diamond Bourse and was a prominent figure in the governance of Antwerp's diamond trading infrastructure.

antwerp-diamond-centre.name: Jean Rosy
antwerp-diamond-centre.bio: Led the Diamond High Council (predecessor to AWDC), overseeing the regulatory and promotional framework of Antwerp's diamond industry.

paideia-the-european-institute-for-jewis.name: Lena Posner-Körösi
paideia-the-european-institute-for-jewis.bio: President of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities who has supported Paideia's mission to revitalize European Jewish intellectual life.

paideia-the-european-institute-for-jewis.name: Ruth Calderon
paideia-the-european-institute-for-jewis.bio: Israeli Talmud scholar, educator, and former Knesset member who has contributed to Paideia's academic programs on Jewish textual literacy in secular contexts.

paideia-the-european-institute-for-jewis.name: Daniel Libeskind
paideia-the-european-institute-for-jewis.bio: World-renowned architect of the Jewish Museum Berlin who has participated in Paideia's programs exploring European Jewish culture and identity.

judiska-f-rsamlingen-i-stockholm.name: Lena Posner-Körösi
judiska-f-rsamlingen-i-stockholm.bio: Prominent leader of Swedish Jewry who has served as president of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities, closely connected to the Stockholm congregation.

judiska-f-rsamlingen-i-stockholm.name: Morton Narrowe
judiska-f-rsamlingen-i-stockholm.bio: American-born rabbi who served as chief rabbi of Stockholm for over 35 years, becoming Sweden's most prominent Jewish religious leader.

judiska-f-rsamlingen-i-stockholm.name: Michael Bart
judiska-f-rsamlingen-i-stockholm.bio: Swedish Jewish communal figure who has held leadership positions within the Judiska Församlingen i Stockholm, managing congregational affairs.

judiska-museet-i-stockholm.name: Aron Verständig
judiska-museet-i-stockholm.bio: President of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities, connected to the governance of the Jewish Museum in Stockholm.

judiska-museet-i-stockholm.name: Hanna Sjöberg
judiska-museet-i-stockholm.bio: Curator at the Judiska Museet who has developed exhibitions documenting the history and cultural contributions of Jews in Sweden since the 18th century.

judiska-museet-i-stockholm.name: Maija Runcis
judiska-museet-i-stockholm.bio: Swedish historian who has contributed scholarly expertise to the Jewish Museum in Stockholm's documentation of Swedish Jewish history and heritage.

official-council-of-swedish-jewish-commu.name: Lena Posner-Körösi
official-council-of-swedish-jewish-commu.bio: Led the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities as its president, representing Sweden's approximately 15,000 Jews in communal and governmental affairs.

official-council-of-swedish-jewish-commu.name: Morton Narrowe
official-council-of-swedish-jewish-commu.bio: Longtime chief rabbi of Stockholm who served as the senior rabbinical figure connected to the Official Council and Swedish Jewish religious life.

official-council-of-swedish-jewish-commu.name: Isak Reichel
official-council-of-swedish-jewish-commu.bio: Served as secretary-general of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities, managing its administrative functions and governmental relations.

raoul-wallenberg-institute.name: Morten Kjaerum
raoul-wallenberg-institute.bio: Danish human rights expert who served as director of the Raoul Wallenberg Institute in Lund, Sweden, and previously led the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights.

raoul-wallenberg-institute.name: Anna Petrig
raoul-wallenberg-institute.bio: International law scholar who has contributed to the Raoul Wallenberg Institute's research on human rights, based at Lund University.

raoul-wallenberg-institute.name: Guy von Dardel
raoul-wallenberg-institute.bio: Physicist and half-brother of Raoul Wallenberg who spent decades campaigning for information about Wallenberg's fate and supporting institutions honoring his legacy.

great-synagogue-of-stockholm.name: Fredrik Vilhelm Scholander
great-synagogue-of-stockholm.bio: Leading Swedish architect who designed the Great Synagogue of Stockholm, completed in 1870 in a Moorish-Egyptian revival style.

great-synagogue-of-stockholm.name: Morton Narrowe
great-synagogue-of-stockholm.bio: American-born rabbi who served as chief rabbi at the Great Synagogue of Stockholm for over 35 years, the longest-serving chief rabbi in Swedish history.

great-synagogue-of-stockholm.name: Marcus Ehrenpreis
great-synagogue-of-stockholm.bio: Galician-born rabbi and author who served as chief rabbi of Stockholm for nearly four decades, becoming a major figure in Swedish cultural and intellectual life.

jewish-museum-stockholm.name: Pontus Ljunghill
jewish-museum-stockholm.bio: Museum director leading the Jewish Museum in Stockholm, which documents the history of Jewish life in Sweden from the 18th century to the present.

jewish-museum-stockholm.name: Aron Verständig
jewish-museum-stockholm.bio: Chairman of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities, connected to the institutional support of the Jewish Museum Stockholm.

jewish-museum-stockholm.name: Hanna Sjöberg
jewish-museum-stockholm.bio: Museum curator involved in developing exhibitions at the Jewish Museum Stockholm on Swedish Jewish identity, immigration history, and cultural heritage.

jewish-community-stockholm.name: Lena Posner-Körösi
jewish-community-stockholm.bio: Prominent Swedish Jewish leader who served as president of the Official Council and has been deeply connected to the Stockholm Jewish community.

jewish-community-stockholm.name: Morton Narrowe
jewish-community-stockholm.bio: Served as chief rabbi of the Jewish Community of Stockholm for over 35 years, shaping Swedish Jewish religious life from 1965 to 2001.

jewish-community-stockholm.name: Isak Reichel
jewish-community-stockholm.bio: Has served as secretary-general of Swedish Jewish communal organizations, contributing to the administrative governance of the Stockholm community.

bonnier-group.name: Albert Bonnier Sr.
bonnier-group.bio: Swedish publisher of Jewish German origin who founded the Bonnier publishing house in 1837, building it into one of Scandinavia's most influential media companies.

bonnier-group.name: Carl-Johan Bonnier
bonnier-group.bio: Sixth-generation member of the Bonnier family who served as chairman of the Bonnier Group, overseeing its media portfolio spanning publishing, broadcasting, and digital media.

bonnier-group.name: Albert Bonnier Jr.
bonnier-group.bio: Third-generation Bonnier publisher who led the Albert Bonniers Förlag publishing house through the mid-20th century, expanding its literary catalog.

doh-ny-street-synagogue-budapest.name: Ludwig Förster
doh-ny-street-synagogue-budapest.bio: Viennese architect who designed the Dohány Street Synagogue in Budapest, completed in 1859 as the largest synagogue in Europe in a Romantic-Moorish style.

doh-ny-street-synagogue-budapest.name: Róbert Frölich
doh-ny-street-synagogue-budapest.bio: Serves as chief rabbi of Hungary at the Dohány Street Synagogue, the seat of the Neolog (Reform) Jewish congregation and the largest synagogue in Europe.

doh-ny-street-synagogue-budapest.name: Péter Feldmájer
doh-ny-street-synagogue-budapest.bio: Hungarian-Jewish communal leader who served as president of the Federation of Hungarian Jewish Communities, overseeing the restoration of the Dohány synagogue complex.

raoul-wallenberg-memorial.name: Imre Varga
raoul-wallenberg-memorial.bio: Hungarian sculptor who created the Raoul Wallenberg Memorial in Budapest, a bronze figure standing near the former Swedish Embassy.

raoul-wallenberg-memorial.name: Per Anger
raoul-wallenberg-memorial.bio: Swedish diplomat who worked alongside Raoul Wallenberg in Budapest in 1944, helping save Hungarian Jews and later advocating for information about Wallenberg's fate.

raoul-wallenberg-memorial.name: Carl Lutz
raoul-wallenberg-memorial.bio: Swiss vice-consul in Budapest who, like Wallenberg, saved tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews during the Holocaust through protective documents and safe houses.

federation-of-hungarian-jewish-communiti.name: Róbert Frölich
federation-of-hungarian-jewish-communiti.bio: Serves as chief rabbi of the Neolog Jewish community in Hungary, the senior rabbinical figure within the MAZSIHISZ federation.

federation-of-hungarian-jewish-communiti.name: Gusztáv Zoltai
federation-of-hungarian-jewish-communiti.bio: Longtime executive director of MAZSIHISZ who managed the day-to-day affairs of Hungarian Jewish communal life for decades.

federation-of-hungarian-jewish-communiti.name: Péter Feldmájer
federation-of-hungarian-jewish-communiti.bio: Hungarian Jewish leader who served as president of MAZSIHISZ, leading the community through the post-Communist transition period and synagogue restoration efforts.

hungarian-jewish-museum.name: András Heisler
hungarian-jewish-museum.bio: As president of the Federation of Hungarian Jewish Communities, oversees the Hungarian Jewish Museum and Archives located within the Dohány synagogue complex.

hungarian-jewish-museum.name: Róbert Frölich
hungarian-jewish-museum.bio: Chief rabbi of Hungary whose work at the Dohány synagogue complex encompasses the Hungarian Jewish Museum's role in preserving Hungarian Jewish heritage.

hungarian-jewish-museum.name: Ilona Seifert
hungarian-jewish-museum.bio: Museum professional involved in curating the Hungarian Jewish Museum's collections of ceremonial objects, historical documents, and Holocaust memorial artifacts.

shoes-on-the-danube-bank.name: Gyula Pauer
shoes-on-the-danube-bank.bio: Hungarian sculptor who created the sixty pairs of cast-iron shoes along the Danube bank in 2005, memorializing thousands of Jews shot into the river in 1944-45.

shoes-on-the-danube-bank.name: Barnabás Holló
shoes-on-the-danube-bank.bio: Hungarian architect who contributed to the design and installation of the Shoes on the Danube Bank memorial along the Pest riverfront.

shoes-on-the-danube-bank.name: Gábor Szegedi
shoes-on-the-danube-bank.bio: Hungarian public figure involved in promoting Budapest Holocaust memorials including the Shoes on the Danube, contributing to their recognition as major memorial sites.

hungarian-jewish-heritage-foundation.name: András Heisler
hungarian-jewish-heritage-foundation.bio: As president of MAZSIHISZ, closely connected to the Hungarian Jewish Heritage Foundation's work preserving synagogues and cultural sites across Hungary.

hungarian-jewish-heritage-foundation.name: Rudolf Klein
hungarian-jewish-heritage-foundation.bio: Hungarian-Israeli architectural historian who has documented and advocated for the preservation of synagogues and Jewish architectural heritage in Hungary.

hungarian-jewish-heritage-foundation.name: Róbert Frölich
hungarian-jewish-heritage-foundation.bio: Chief rabbi of Hungary who provides religious guidance and support to heritage preservation efforts for Hungarian Jewish cultural sites and communities.

ort-hungary.name: Robert Singer
ort-hungary.bio: Israeli-British executive who led World ORT as its CEO, overseeing the global Jewish educational network's operations including programs in Hungary.

ort-hungary.name: András Heisler
ort-hungary.bio: President of MAZSIHISZ who supports ORT Hungary's educational mission within the broader framework of Hungarian Jewish communal institutions.

ort-hungary.name: Vera Szőke
ort-hungary.bio: Educator involved in directing ORT Hungary's programs providing technology education and vocational training within Hungary's Jewish community.

dohany-street-synagogue.name: Ludwig Förster
dohany-street-synagogue.bio: Viennese architect who designed the Dohány Street Synagogue, completed in 1859 in a Moorish Revival style, making it Europe's largest synagogue.

dohany-street-synagogue.name: Frigyes Feszl
dohany-street-synagogue.bio: Hungarian architect who designed the ornate interior decorations of the Dohány Street Synagogue, contributing to its distinctive Romantic-Moorish aesthetic.

dohany-street-synagogue.name: Péter Feldmájer
dohany-street-synagogue.bio: Led the Federation of Hungarian Jewish Communities during the major restoration of the Dohány Street Synagogue complex in the 1990s.

turkish-jewish-community.name: Ishak Ibrahimzadeh
turkish-jewish-community.bio: President of the Turkish Jewish Community, managing its communal affairs and representing Turkey's approximately 15,000 Jews, mostly based in Istanbul.

turkish-jewish-community.name: Jak Kamhi
turkish-jewish-community.bio: Turkish-Jewish industrialist and founder of the Quincentennial Foundation who has been a leading figure in promoting Turkish-Jewish heritage and interfaith dialogue.

turkish-jewish-community.name: Bensiyon Pinto
turkish-jewish-community.bio: Served as president of the Turkish Jewish Community, leading communal governance and representation during a period of community revitalization.

t-rkiye-musevi-cemaati.name: İshak Haleva
t-rkiye-musevi-cemaati.bio: Serves as Hakham Bashi (Chief Rabbi) of Turkey since 2002, the spiritual leader of the Turkish Sephardic Jewish community.

t-rkiye-musevi-cemaati.name: Jak Kamhi
t-rkiye-musevi-cemaati.bio: Prominent Turkish-Jewish businessman who founded Profilo Holding and the Quincentennial Foundation, a leading advocate for Turkish-Jewish heritage.

t-rkiye-musevi-cemaati.name: Silvyo Ovadya
t-rkiye-musevi-cemaati.bio: Served as president of the Turkish Jewish Community and chairman of the Quincentennial Foundation, representing Turkish Jewry in public affairs.

museum-of-turkish-jews.name: Naim Güleryüz
museum-of-turkish-jews.bio: Turkish-Jewish historian who documented the 500-year history of Jews in the Ottoman Empire and Turkey, serving as historian for the Museum of Turkish Jews.

museum-of-turkish-jews.name: Jak Kamhi
museum-of-turkish-jews.bio: Turkish-Jewish industrialist who founded the Quincentennial Foundation in 1992 to commemorate 500 years of Jewish life in Turkey, establishing the museum.

museum-of-turkish-jews.name: Silvyo Ovadya
museum-of-turkish-jews.bio: Led the Quincentennial Foundation that operates the Museum of Turkish Jews, promoting awareness of Sephardic Jewish heritage in Turkey.

neve-shalom-synagogue.name: Jak Kamhi
neve-shalom-synagogue.bio: Prominent Turkish-Jewish industrialist and community leader closely connected to the Neve Shalom synagogue, which was targeted in terrorist attacks in 1986 and 2003.

neve-shalom-synagogue.name: David Asseo
neve-shalom-synagogue.bio: Served as chief rabbi of Turkey before İshak Haleva, leading the community from the Neve Shalom synagogue, the main synagogue of Istanbul.

neve-shalom-synagogue.name: Ishak Ibrahimzadeh
neve-shalom-synagogue.bio: President of the Turkish Jewish Community who oversees Neve Shalom synagogue, Istanbul's principal Sephardic house of worship.

ahrida-synagogue-istanbul.name: İshak Haleva
ahrida-synagogue-istanbul.bio: Chief Rabbi of Turkey who oversees the religious life of historic Istanbul synagogues including the Ahrida, one of the oldest in the city dating to the 15th century.

ahrida-synagogue-istanbul.name: Naim Güleryüz
ahrida-synagogue-istanbul.bio: Turkish-Jewish historian who has documented the history of the Ahrida Synagogue, one of Istanbul's most important Romaniot and Sephardic heritage sites.

ahrida-synagogue-istanbul.name: Ishak Ibrahimzadeh
ahrida-synagogue-istanbul.bio: President of the Turkish Jewish community responsible for the preservation and maintenance of historic Istanbul synagogues including the Ahrida.

quincentennial-foundation-museum-istanbu.name: Jak Kamhi
quincentennial-foundation-museum-istanbu.bio: Turkish-Jewish industrialist who founded the Quincentennial Foundation in 1992 to commemorate 500 years since the Ottoman welcome of Sephardic Jews expelled from Spain.

quincentennial-foundation-museum-istanbu.name: Silvyo Ovadya
quincentennial-foundation-museum-istanbu.bio: Former president of the Turkish Jewish Community who served as chairman of the Quincentennial Foundation, overseeing its museum and cultural programs.

quincentennial-foundation-museum-istanbu.name: Ishak Ibrahimzadeh
quincentennial-foundation-museum-istanbu.bio: President of the Turkish Jewish Community who supports the Quincentennial Foundation Museum's mission to document 500 years of Jewish life in Turkey.

chief-rabbinate-of-turkey.name: David Asseo
chief-rabbinate-of-turkey.bio: Served as chief rabbi (Hakham Bashi) of Turkey before İshak Haleva, leading the Sephardic community's religious affairs.

chief-rabbinate-of-turkey.name: Rafael Saban
chief-rabbinate-of-turkey.bio: Served as chief rabbi of Turkey in the mid-20th century, guiding the Sephardic community through a period of modernization and demographic change.

chief-rabbinate-of-turkey.name: Jak Kamhi
chief-rabbinate-of-turkey.bio: Leading Turkish-Jewish industrialist and communal figure who has supported the chief rabbinate's institutional and cultural activities.

quincentennial-foundation-turkey.name: Jak Kamhi
quincentennial-foundation-turkey.bio: Turkish-Jewish industrialist and founder of Profilo Holding who established the Quincentennial Foundation in 1992 to celebrate and preserve Turkish-Jewish heritage.

quincentennial-foundation-turkey.name: Naim Güleryüz
quincentennial-foundation-turkey.bio: Leading Turkish-Jewish historian who has documented the history of the Jewish community in Turkey for the Quincentennial Foundation's publications and museum.

quincentennial-foundation-turkey.name: İshak Haleva
quincentennial-foundation-turkey.bio: Chief Rabbi of Turkey who supports the Quincentennial Foundation's mission to preserve the legacy of 500 years of Jewish life in Turkey.

jewish-quarter-of-prague-josefov.name: Rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel
jewish-quarter-of-prague-josefov.bio: Known as the Maharal of Prague, a renowned Talmudist and philosopher connected to the legend of the Golem, who led the Jewish community in Josefov.

jewish-quarter-of-prague-josefov.name: Mordechai Maisel
jewish-quarter-of-prague-josefov.bio: Wealthy Jewish financier and mayor of Prague's Jewish quarter who funded the construction of synagogues, streets, and the first Jewish town hall in Josefov.

jewish-quarter-of-prague-josefov.name: Franz Kafka
jewish-quarter-of-prague-josefov.bio: Prague-born Jewish author of seminal 20th century literature who grew up adjacent to Josefov and whose works reflect the atmosphere of Prague's Jewish quarter.

old-new-synagogue-altneuschul.name: Karol Sidon
old-new-synagogue-altneuschul.role: Former Chief Rabbi of Czech Republic
old-new-synagogue-altneuschul.bio: Czech author and rabbi who served as chief rabbi of Prague and the Czech Republic, leading services at the Old-New Synagogue, Europe's oldest active synagogue.

old-new-synagogue-altneuschul.name: Mordechai Maisel
old-new-synagogue-altneuschul.bio: Renaissance-era Jewish financier and philanthropist who supported the synagogues and institutions of Prague's Jewish quarter during the Maharal's era.

old-new-synagogue-altneuschul.name: Avigdor Kara
old-new-synagogue-altneuschul.bio: Medieval rabbi and poet of the Prague Jewish community whose gravestone in the Old Jewish Cemetery is the oldest preserved, and who witnessed the 1389 Easter pogrom.

federace-idovsk-ch-obc-v-esk-republice.name: Tomáš Kraus
federace-idovsk-ch-obc-v-esk-republice.bio: Longtime executive director of the Federation of Jewish Communities in the Czech Republic, managing communal affairs and representing Czech Jewry internationally.

federace-idovsk-ch-obc-v-esk-republice.name: Karol Sidon
federace-idovsk-ch-obc-v-esk-republice.bio: Czech writer and rabbi who served as chief rabbi of the Czech Republic, providing religious leadership within the federation's institutional framework.

federace-idovsk-ch-obc-v-esk-republice.name: David Peter
federace-idovsk-ch-obc-v-esk-republice.bio: Czech Jewish communal leader who has contributed to the federation's work in rebuilding and sustaining Jewish community life in the post-Communist Czech Republic.

terez-n-memorial.name: Vojtěch Blodig
terez-n-memorial.bio: Longtime deputy director and historian at the Terezín Memorial who has authored major studies on the Theresienstadt ghetto and its role in the Holocaust.

terez-n-memorial.name: Hans Krása
terez-n-memorial.bio: Czech-Jewish composer who created the children's opera 'Brundibár' performed in Terezín, murdered in Auschwitz; his work became a symbol of cultural resistance during the Holocaust.

terez-n-memorial.name: Norbert Troller
terez-n-memorial.bio: Czech-Jewish architect and artist who was interned in Terezín and secretly documented camp life through drawings, which became key historical evidence.

jewish-museum-in-prague.name: Michal Frankl
jewish-museum-in-prague.bio: Czech historian specializing in antisemitism and Jewish history who has served in leadership at the Jewish Museum in Prague, one of the world's oldest Jewish museums.

jewish-museum-in-prague.name: Hana Volavková
jewish-museum-in-prague.bio: Czech-Jewish art historian who directed the Jewish Museum in Prague after WWII, preserving its extraordinary collections of confiscated ceremonial objects and children's drawings from Terezín.

jewish-museum-in-prague.name: Arno Pařík
jewish-museum-in-prague.bio: Longtime senior curator at the Jewish Museum in Prague who has developed exhibitions and documented Czech and Bohemian Jewish history and material culture.

old-jewish-cemetery-prague.name: Mordechai Maisel
old-jewish-cemetery-prague.bio: Renaissance Jewish financier and mayor of the Prague ghetto whose elaborate tombstone is among the most visited in the cemetery, which contains over 12,000 headstones.

old-jewish-cemetery-prague.name: David Gans
old-jewish-cemetery-prague.bio: Czech-Jewish astronomer and chronicler buried in the Old Jewish Cemetery, known for his historical work 'Zemach David' and his collaboration with Tycho Brahe.

old-jewish-cemetery-prague.name: Rabbi David Oppenheim
old-jewish-cemetery-prague.bio: Chief rabbi of Prague who amassed the most important Hebrew book collection in the world, buried in the Old Jewish Cemetery.

federation-of-jewish-communities-in-the-.name: Tomáš Kraus
federation-of-jewish-communities-in-the-.bio: Serves as executive director of the Federation, coordinating Czech Jewish communal life, heritage preservation, and international representation.

federation-of-jewish-communities-in-the-.name: Karol Sidon
federation-of-jewish-communities-in-the-.bio: Prominent Czech author who became chief rabbi of the Czech Republic after the Velvet Revolution, leading the revival of Czech Jewish religious life.

federation-of-jewish-communities-in-the-.name: David Peter
federation-of-jewish-communities-in-the-.bio: Active in the federation's governance, contributing to the rebuilding of Czech Jewish institutional and community life after four decades of Communist rule.

pinkas-synagogue-prague-holocaust-memori.name: Hana Volavková
pinkas-synagogue-prague-holocaust-memori.bio: Czech-Jewish art historian who oversaw the transformation of the Pinkas Synagogue into a Holocaust memorial with the names of 77,297 Czech and Moravian Jewish victims inscribed on its walls.

pinkas-synagogue-prague-holocaust-memori.name: Arno Pařík
pinkas-synagogue-prague-holocaust-memori.bio: Senior curator at the Jewish Museum in Prague who has researched and documented the Pinkas Synagogue's Holocaust memorial and its children's drawings from Terezín.

pinkas-synagogue-prague-holocaust-memori.name: Leo Pavlát
pinkas-synagogue-prague-holocaust-memori.bio: Former director of the Jewish Museum in Prague who oversaw the Pinkas Synagogue memorial's restoration and its preservation as a major Holocaust remembrance site.

conseil-des-communaut-s-isra-lites-du-ma.name: André Azoulay
conseil-des-communaut-s-isra-lites-du-ma.bio: Jewish Moroccan businessman and senior adviser to King Mohammed VI who champions interfaith dialogue and the preservation of Moroccan Jewish heritage.

conseil-des-communaut-s-isra-lites-du-ma.name: Jacky Kadoch
conseil-des-communaut-s-isra-lites-du-ma.bio: Moroccan Jewish communal figure involved in the governance of the Council of Israelite Communities, helping maintain Jewish institutional life in Morocco.

conseil-des-communaut-s-isra-lites-du-ma.name: Simon Levy
conseil-des-communaut-s-isra-lites-du-ma.bio: Moroccan-Jewish scholar and founder of the Museum of Moroccan Judaism in Casablanca, who documented the history of Jewish life in Morocco.

museum-of-moroccan-judaism.name: Simon Levy
museum-of-moroccan-judaism.bio: Moroccan-Jewish professor and historian who founded the Museum of Moroccan Judaism in Casablanca in 1997, the only Jewish museum in the Arab world.

museum-of-moroccan-judaism.name: Serge Berdugo
museum-of-moroccan-judaism.bio: Secretary-general of the Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco who has supported the museum as a centerpiece of Moroccan Jewish heritage preservation.

museum-of-moroccan-judaism.name: André Azoulay
museum-of-moroccan-judaism.bio: Senior adviser to King Mohammed VI and a champion of Moroccan Jewish heritage preservation, supporting the museum's mission of documenting Jewish life in Morocco.

bayt-dakira-house-of-memory.name: Serge Berdugo
bayt-dakira-house-of-memory.bio: Secretary-general of the Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco who supports Bayt Dakira's mission of preserving Jewish heritage in Essaouira.

bayt-dakira-house-of-memory.name: Audrey Azoulay
bayt-dakira-house-of-memory.bio: Daughter of André Azoulay, French-Moroccan diplomat serving as UNESCO Director-General, connected to the family's commitment to Moroccan-Jewish heritage preservation.

bayt-dakira-house-of-memory.name: Tahar Ben Jelloun
bayt-dakira-house-of-memory.bio: Moroccan-French author and intellectual who has supported initiatives preserving Morocco's Jewish-Muslim coexistence heritage, including the Essaouira projects.

council-of-jewish-communities-of-morocco.name: Serge Berdugo
council-of-jewish-communities-of-morocco.bio: Former Moroccan Minister of Tourism who has served as secretary-general of the Council, the central body representing Morocco's Jewish communities.

council-of-jewish-communities-of-morocco.name: Jacky Kadoch
council-of-jewish-communities-of-morocco.bio: Active in the governance of the Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco, contributing to the maintenance of Jewish communal institutions across the country.

council-of-jewish-communities-of-morocco.name: Simon Levy
council-of-jewish-communities-of-morocco.bio: Moroccan-Jewish historian whose scholarly work and founding of the Museum of Moroccan Judaism contributed to the Council's heritage preservation mission.

rabbi-haim-pinto-synagogue-essaouira.name: André Azoulay
rabbi-haim-pinto-synagogue-essaouira.bio: Jewish Moroccan royal adviser and prominent Essaouira native who has championed the preservation of the city's Jewish heritage sites including the Pinto synagogue.

rabbi-haim-pinto-synagogue-essaouira.name: Serge Berdugo
rabbi-haim-pinto-synagogue-essaouira.bio: Secretary-general of the Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco who supports the preservation of historic synagogues including the Rabbi Haim Pinto Synagogue in Essaouira.

rabbi-haim-pinto-synagogue-essaouira.name: Rabbi Yoshiyahu Pinto
rabbi-haim-pinto-synagogue-essaouira.bio: Prominent Israeli-Moroccan rabbi and descendant of Rabbi Haim Pinto who leads an international following and maintains the family's spiritual legacy connected to Essaouira.

casablanca-jewish-heritage-trail.name: André Azoulay
casablanca-jewish-heritage-trail.bio: Senior adviser to King Mohammed VI and champion of Moroccan Jewish heritage who has supported the development of Jewish heritage tourism in Casablanca.

casablanca-jewish-heritage-trail.name: Zhor Rehihil
casablanca-jewish-heritage-trail.bio: Curator of the Museum of Moroccan Judaism in Casablanca who contributes expertise to the preservation and presentation of Jewish heritage sites in the city.

casablanca-jewish-heritage-trail.name: Simon Levy
casablanca-jewish-heritage-trail.bio: Moroccan-Jewish scholar whose research on Jewish life in Casablanca and across Morocco laid the groundwork for heritage trail initiatives.

conseil-des-communautes-israelites-du-ma.name: André Azoulay
conseil-des-communautes-israelites-du-ma.bio: Prominent Moroccan-Jewish adviser to King Mohammed VI who works closely with the Council on matters of Jewish heritage preservation and interfaith relations.

conseil-des-communautes-israelites-du-ma.name: Jacky Kadoch
conseil-des-communautes-israelites-du-ma.bio: Moroccan Jewish figure active in the Council's governance, helping represent and maintain Jewish communal institutions across Morocco.

conseil-des-communautes-israelites-du-ma.name: Simon Levy
conseil-des-communautes-israelites-du-ma.bio: Moroccan-Jewish professor and social activist who founded the Casablanca Jewish museum and contributed to the Council's cultural preservation mission.

babyn-yar-holocaust-memorial-center.name: Ilya Khrzhanovsky
babyn-yar-holocaust-memorial-center.bio: Russian-born film director who served as artistic director of the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center, developing its innovative but controversial memorial concepts.

babyn-yar-holocaust-memorial-center.name: Ronald Lauder
babyn-yar-holocaust-memorial-center.bio: American billionaire and World Jewish Congress president who has supported the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center's mission to commemorate the massacre of over 33,000 Jews in 1941.

babyn-yar-holocaust-memorial-center.name: Yana Barinova
babyn-yar-holocaust-memorial-center.bio: Served as CEO of the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center, managing its operations and the development of the memorial complex in Kyiv.

golden-rose-synagogue-lviv-ruins.name: Meylakh Sheykhet
golden-rose-synagogue-lviv-ruins.bio: Ukrainian Jewish leader and representative of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews who has championed the preservation and memorialization of the Golden Rose Synagogue ruins in Lviv.

golden-rose-synagogue-lviv-ruins.name: Boris Lozhkin
golden-rose-synagogue-lviv-ruins.bio: President of the Jewish Confederation of Ukraine who has supported efforts to preserve and memorialize Ukrainian Jewish heritage sites including the Golden Rose Synagogue.

golden-rose-synagogue-lviv-ruins.name: Nachman Krochmal
golden-rose-synagogue-lviv-ruins.bio: Galician Jewish philosopher and historian from Lviv who was one of the founders of the Wissenschaft des Judentums movement and connected to Lviv's Jewish intellectual life.

menorah-center-dnipro.name: Ihor Kolomoyskyi
menorah-center-dnipro.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish billionaire who co-funded the construction of the Menorah Center in Dnipro, the world's largest Jewish community center, opened in 2012.

menorah-center-dnipro.name: Rabbi Shmuel Kaminezki
menorah-center-dnipro.bio: Chabad rabbi serving as chief rabbi of Dnipro who provides spiritual leadership at the Menorah Center, a seven-branched building symbolizing the menorah.

menorah-center-dnipro.name: Jonathan Markovitch
menorah-center-dnipro.bio: Has served in the leadership of the Menorah Center in Dnipro, managing its community facilities, museum, and cultural programming.

uman-breslov-pilgrimage.name: Rabbi Nathan of Breslov
uman-breslov-pilgrimage.bio: Chief disciple of Rabbi Nachman of Breslov who compiled and preserved his master's teachings, establishing the tradition of annual pilgrimage to Nachman's grave in Uman.

uman-breslov-pilgrimage.name: Rabbi Nachman Burstein
uman-breslov-pilgrimage.bio: Breslov elder and leader who helped revive the annual Rosh Hashanah pilgrimage to Uman after the fall of the Soviet Union, when gatherings swelled from hundreds to tens of thousands.

uman-breslov-pilgrimage.name: Rabbi Eliezer Shlomo Schick
uman-breslov-pilgrimage.bio: Prominent Breslov rabbi and author who led a large following and was instrumental in organizing the annual Uman pilgrimage gatherings.

jewish-confederation-of-ukraine.name: Vadim Rabinovich
jewish-confederation-of-ukraine.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish businessman and politician who co-founded the Jewish Confederation of Ukraine and served as a member of the Ukrainian parliament.

jewish-confederation-of-ukraine.name: Josef Zissels
jewish-confederation-of-ukraine.bio: Chairman of the Association of Jewish Organizations and Communities of Ukraine (VAAD) and a leading Ukrainian Jewish communal figure and human rights activist.

jewish-confederation-of-ukraine.name: Ihor Kolomoyskyi
jewish-confederation-of-ukraine.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish billionaire and former governor of Dnipropetrovsk Oblast who has supported Jewish communal institutions in Ukraine.

united-jewish-community-of-ukraine.name: Boris Lozhkin
united-jewish-community-of-ukraine.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish businessman and former head of the Presidential Administration of Ukraine who serves as president of the United Jewish Community of Ukraine.

united-jewish-community-of-ukraine.name: Josef Zissels
united-jewish-community-of-ukraine.bio: Longtime Ukrainian Jewish leader and chairman of VAAD who participates in the United Jewish Community's coordination of Ukrainian Jewry.

united-jewish-community-of-ukraine.name: Ihor Kolomoyskyi
united-jewish-community-of-ukraine.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish billionaire and co-founder of PrivatBank who has been a major financial supporter of Jewish communal organizations in Ukraine.

ukrainian-jewish-confederation.name: Vadim Rabinovich
ukrainian-jewish-confederation.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish businessman and politician who has led the Ukrainian Jewish Confederation, representing Jewish community interests in Ukrainian public life.

ukrainian-jewish-confederation.name: Josef Zissels
ukrainian-jewish-confederation.bio: Chairman of the Association of Jewish Organizations and Communities of Ukraine, a key leader in the umbrella structure of Ukrainian Jewish communal organizations.

ukrainian-jewish-confederation.name: Ihor Kolomoyskyi
ukrainian-jewish-confederation.bio: Billionaire businessman who has supported Ukrainian Jewish institutions and is one of the most prominent Jewish figures in Ukrainian public life.

toyota-motor-corporation.name: Kiichiro Toyoda
toyota-motor-corporation.bio: Japanese industrialist who founded Toyota Motor Corporation in 1937, transitioning the family business from automatic looms to automobile manufacturing.

toyota-motor-corporation.name: Koji Sato
toyota-motor-corporation.bio: Serves as president and CEO of Toyota Motor Corporation, leading the world's largest automaker through its transition to electric and hydrogen-powered vehicles.

toyota-motor-corporation.name: Eiji Toyoda
toyota-motor-corporation.bio: Nephew of the founder who led Toyota's post-war expansion and championed the Toyota Production System, transforming it into a global automotive giant.

jewish-community-of-kobe.name: Anatole Ponevejsky
jewish-community-of-kobe.bio: President of the Kobe Jewish community during WWII who coordinated aid for Jewish refugees transiting through Japan, helping thousands escape the Holocaust.

jewish-community-of-kobe.name: Alex Einbinder
jewish-community-of-kobe.bio: Leader of the Kobe Jewish community who has worked to maintain the congregation and preserve its history as a refuge for Jewish refugees during World War II.

jewish-community-of-kobe.name: Zerach Warhaftig
jewish-community-of-kobe.bio: Polish-Jewish leader and future Israeli government minister who helped organize the transit of Jewish refugees through Kobe during WWII with the aid of Chiune Sugihara's visas.

makuya.name: Takeji Otsuki
makuya.bio: Succeeded Abraham Ikuro Teshima as leader of the Makuya movement, continuing its mission of Christian-Zionist engagement and promoting Japanese-Israeli relations.

makuya.name: Yamamoto Shichihei
makuya.bio: Japanese author and social commentator who wrote about Judaism and Jewish culture for Japanese audiences, contributing to the intellectual context of the Makuya movement.

makuya.name: Miriam Teshima
makuya.bio: Member of the Teshima family who has continued the Makuya movement's tradition of pilgrimage to Israel and engagement with Jewish communities worldwide.

sugihara-museum-yaotsu.name: Yukiko Sugihara
sugihara-museum-yaotsu.bio: Wife of Chiune Sugihara who supported his decision to issue life-saving visas and later helped preserve his legacy through memoirs and public appearances.

sugihara-museum-yaotsu.name: Nobuki Sugihara
sugihara-museum-yaotsu.bio: Son of Chiune Sugihara who has worked to preserve his father's legacy as a Righteous Among the Nations, supporting the museum in Yaotsu and related educational programs.

sugihara-museum-yaotsu.name: Solly Ganor
sugihara-museum-yaotsu.bio: Lithuanian-Jewish Holocaust survivor who received a Sugihara visa as a child and later wrote about the experience, becoming an advocate for the museum and Sugihara's legacy.

jewish-community-of-japan.name: Marvin Tokayer
jewish-community-of-japan.bio: American rabbi who served as rabbi of the Jewish Community of Japan in Tokyo for over a decade, becoming the foremost chronicler of Jewish-Japanese relations.

jewish-community-of-japan.name: David Kunin
jewish-community-of-japan.bio: Has served as rabbi of the Jewish Community of Japan in Tokyo, leading religious services and community events for the expatriate and local Jewish population.

jewish-community-of-japan.name: Michael Goldstein
jewish-community-of-japan.bio: Has served in leadership of the Jewish Community of Japan in Tokyo, overseeing the small but active community's religious, social, and cultural programs.

kobe-jewish-community.name: Chiune Sugihara
kobe-jewish-community.bio: Japanese diplomat whose transit visas enabled thousands of Jewish refugees to reach Kobe in 1940-41, making the Kobe Jewish community a critical wartime refuge.

kobe-jewish-community.name: Kalman Rotter
kobe-jewish-community.bio: Rabbi who served the Jewish refugee community in Kobe during WWII, providing religious leadership to the thousands of Jews who transited through the city.

kobe-jewish-community.name: Jan Zwartendijk
kobe-jewish-community.bio: Dutch honorary consul in Kaunas, Lithuania who issued destination visas to Curaçao enabling Jewish refugees to obtain Sugihara's transit visas and reach Kobe.

softbank-group.name: Marcelo Claure
softbank-group.bio: Bolivian-American businessman who served as COO of SoftBank Group and CEO of SoftBank International, managing key portfolio companies and operations.

softbank-group.name: Rajeev Misra
softbank-group.role: Former Head of SoftBank Vision Fund
softbank-group.bio: Indian-British banker who led the SoftBank Vision Fund, one of the world's largest technology investment vehicles at $100 billion.

softbank-group.name: Nikesh Arora
softbank-group.bio: Indian-American executive who served as president and COO of SoftBank Group from 2014 to 2016, previously a top executive at Google.
